definition: to hear litigation (in a law court)/to hear a case
to listen/to hear/to obey/a can (loanword from English "tin")/classifier for canned beverages
smile (archaic)
(literary pronunciation, still advocated in Taiwan) to rule/to sentence/to allow
litigation

sentences.english: The hearing didn't last long. "Guilty, " the magistrate said.
sentences.chinese: 听讼没有持续很长时间，“有罪”检察官说到。

sentences.english: Do not be afraid of any man, for judgment belongs to God.
sentences.chinese: 听讼不可分贵贱，不可惧怕人，因为审判是属乎神的。

sentences.english: Lawyers for the opposition MDC said the hearing has been delayed until Sunday.
sentences.chinese: 反对党民革运律师表示听讼会被延期至周日。

definition: to judge (i.e. to hear and pass judgment in a law court)/to hear and decide
to pass judgment on a legal case
a hard legal case to judge
to secure a position/to take an official appointment
dispute involving litigation/legal dispute
justly/impartially
see 諍諫|诤谏[zheng4 jian4]
Imperial scholar from the Ming Dynasty onwards
see 諍諫|诤谏[zheng4 jian4]
to suffer injustice
to attend/to take office/to be present (in administrative capacity)
to encourage and supervise (esp. state officials promoting agriculture)
benevolent government
laws and decrees
xing-ming, a school of thought of the Warring States period associated with Shen Buhai 申不害[Shen1 Bu4 hai4]/the designation for a punishment
benevolent policy/humane government
